titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Stanford University, Campaign for Undergraduate Education, Think Again Film and Brochure SCM0248
Stanford University, Campaign for Undergraduate Education, Think Again Film and Brochure
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Daniel Hartwig

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-05-13T09:44-0700

did.unittitle: Stanford University, Campaign for Undergraduate Education, Think Again film and brochure

repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Stanford University. Campaign for Undergraduate Education.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: DVD of the film shown during the Think Again national tour with brochure of the credits and cast. The film includes interviews with alumni and students, performances by student a cappella groups, and academic profiles.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Think Again Tour, intended to reacquaint alumni with the university, was one component of the Campaign for Undergraduate Education, a five-year drive to raise a $1 billion endowment for new initiatives.

accessrestrict.head: Access to Collection
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research use.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94305-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/spc/using-collections/permission-publish.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.
